1import pandas as pd 

2import rdkit.Chem as Chem 

3 

4from joblib import Parallel, delayed 

5from SynRBL.rsmi_utils import save_database 

6 

7from typing import Tuple 

8 

9 

10class RSMIProcessing: 

11 """ 

12 A class to process reaction SMILES (RSMI) data. 

13 

14 Parameters 

15 ---------- 

16 rsmi : str, optional 

17 The reaction SMILES string to be processed. 

18 data : DataFrame, optional 

19 The DataFrame containing the RSMI data. 

20 rsmi_col : str, optional 

21 The column name in the DataFrame that contains the RSMI data. 

22 symbol : str, optional 

23 The symbol that separates reactants and products in the RSMI string (default is '>>'). 

24 n_jobs : int, optional 

25 The number of jobs to run in parallel (default is 10). 

26 verbose : int, optional 

27 The verbosity level (default is 1). 

28 parallel : bool, optional 

29 Whether to use parallel processing (default is True). 

30 save_json : bool, optional 

31 Whether to save the processed data to a JSON file (default is True). 

32 save_path_name : str, optional 

33 The path and name of the JSON file to save (default is 'reaction.json.gz'). 

34 orient : str, optional 

35 The orientation of the JSON file (default is 'records'). 

36 compression : str, optional 

37 The compression type for the JSON file (default is 'gzip'). 

38 

39 Example 

40 ------- 

41 # Create an instance of the RSMIProcessing class with a DataFrame 

42 >>> data = pd.DataFrame({'rsmi': ['CCO>>CCOCC', 'CC>>C']}) 

43 >>> processor = RSMIProcessing(data=data, rsmi_col='rsmi', parallel=False) 

44 # Split the RSMI data into reactants and products 

45 >>> processed_data = processor.data_splitter() 

46 # Display the processed data 

47 >>> print(processed_data) 

48 """ 

49 

50 def __init__( 

51 self, 

52 reaction_smiles: str = None, 

53 data: pd.DataFrame = None, 

54 data_name: str = "USPTO_50K", 

55 index_col: str = "R-id", 

56 rsmi_col: str = None, 

57 symbol: str = ">>", 

58 n_jobs: int = 4, 

59 drop_duplicates: bool = True, 

60 verbose: int = 1, 

61 parallel: bool = True, 

62 save_json: bool = True, 

63 save_path_name: str = "reaction.json.gz", 

64 orient: str = "records", 

65 compression: str = "gzip", 

66 ) -> None: 

67 self.reaction_smiles = reaction_smiles 

68 self.symbol = symbol 

69 self.n_jobs = n_jobs 

70 self.verbose = verbose 

71 self.parallel = parallel 

72 self.data = data 

73 self.data_name = data_name 

74 self.index_col = index_col 

75 self.drop_duplicates = drop_duplicates 

76 self.rsmi_col = rsmi_col 

77 self.save_json = save_json 

78 self.save_path_name = save_path_name 

79 self.orient = orient 

80 self.compression = compression 

81 

82 @staticmethod 

83 def smi_splitter(rsmi: str, symbol: str = ">>") -> Tuple[str, str]: 

84 """ 

85 Split a RSMI string into reactants and products. 

86 

87 Returns 

88 ------- 

89 tuple 

90 The reactants and products as separate strings, if the RSMI string can be parsed. 

91 str 

92 A message indicating the RSMI string can't be parsed, if applicable. 

93 """ 

94 

95 # Check if the RSMI string can be parsed 

96 if RSMIProcessing.can_parse(rsmi, symbol): 

97 # Split the RSMI string into reactants and products 

98 return rsmi.split(symbol) 

99 else: 

100 # Return a message if the RSMI string cannot be parsed 

101 return "Can't parse" 

102 

103 def data_splitter(self) -> pd.DataFrame: 

104 """ 

105 Split the RSMI data in the DataFrame into reactants and products. 

106 

107 Returns 

108 ------- 

109 DataFrame 

110 The processed DataFrame with separate columns for reactants and products. 

111 

112 Example 

113 ------- 

114 >>> data = pd.DataFrame({'rsmi': ['C>>CC', 'CC>>CCC']}) 

115 >>> processor = RSMIProcessing(data=data, rsmi_col='rsmi', parallel=False) 

116 >>> processed_data = processor.data_splitter() 

117 >>> print(processed_data) 

118 """ 

119 # Check if parallel processing is enabled 

120 if self.parallel: 

121 # Use joblib's Parallel to concurrently process each RSMI string in the DataFrame 

122 # 'can_parse' function is applied to each RSMI string to check if it's parsable 

123 parsable = Parallel(n_jobs=self.n_jobs, verbose=self.verbose)( 

124 delayed(RSMIProcessing.can_parse)(rsmi) 

125 for rsmi in self.data[self.rsmi_col].values 

126 ) 

127 # Filter the data to include only parsable RSMI strings 

128 self.data = self.data[parsable] 

129 else: 

130 # If parallel processing is not enabled, apply 'can_parse' function sequentially 

131 # to each RSMI string in the DataFrame and filter parsable ones 

132 self.data = self.data[ 

133 self.data[self.rsmi_col].apply(RSMIProcessing.can_parse) 

134 ] 

135 

136 # Split each RSMI string in the DataFrame into reactants and products 

137 # 'expand=True' splits the string into separate columns 

138 split_smiles = self.data[self.rsmi_col].str.split(self.symbol, expand=True) 

139 

140 # Assign the first part of the split (reactants) to a new column in the DataFrame 

141 self.data["reactants"] = split_smiles[0] 

142 # Assign the second part of the split (products) to another new column 

143 self.data["products"] = split_smiles[1] 

144 

145 if self.drop_duplicates: 

146 self.data.drop_duplicates(subset=self.rsmi_col, inplace=True) 

147 self.data.reset_index(drop=True, inplace=True) 

148 self.data[self.index_col] = [ 

149 self.data_name + "_" if self.data_name is not None else "" + str(i) 

150 for i in self.data.index 

151 ] 

152 # Check if there's a need to save the processed data to a JSON file 

153 if self.save_json: 

154 data = self.data.to_dict(orient=self.orient) 

155 save_database(data, self.save_path_name) 

156 # Save the DataFrame to a JSON file with specified format and compression 

157 # self.data.to_json(self.save_path_name, orient=self.orient, compression=self.compression) 

158 

159 # Return the processed DataFrame with separate columns for reactants and products 

160 return self.data 

161 

162 @staticmethod 

163 def can_parse(rsmi: str, symbol: str = ">>") -> bool: 

164 """ 

165 Check if a RSMI string can be parsed into reactants and products. 

166 

167 Parameters 

168 ---------- 

169 rsmi : str 

170 The reaction smiles (RSMI) string to be checked for parsability. 

171 symbol : str, optional 

172 The symbol used to separate reactants and products in the RSMI string (default is '>>'). 

173 

174 Returns 

175 ------- 

176 bool 

177 True if the RSMI string can be parsed into valid reactant and product SMILES, False otherwise. 

178 """ 

179 

180 # Split the RSMI string into reactants and products using the provided symbol 

181 react, prod = rsmi.split(symbol) 

182 

183 # Check if both reactants and products can be converted into RDKit molecule objects 

184 return ( 

185 Chem.MolFromSmiles(prod) is not None 

186 and Chem.MolFromSmiles(react) is not None 

187 )
